Fork

Basic Usage

First you'll need to import the fork.js library into your page. You can load it from GitHub if you don't want to host it yourself. 
<script src="https://edsu.github.io/fork/fork.js"></script>
Then mark up any <ul> elements you would like to fork with the class fork which will automatically randomly select from one of the options. When you click on the fork it will randomly select one of the other options. 
<div>

An owl and a girl most

<ul class="fork">
  <li>adventurous</li>
  <li>curious</li>
  <li>studious</li>
</ul>

<ul class="fork">
  <li>set out</li>
  <li>set sail</li>
  <li>sailed away</li>
</ul>

in a

<ul class="fork">
  <li>bottle-green</li>
  <li>beetle-green</li>
  <li>pea-green</li>
</ul>

<ul class="fork">
  <li>boat;</li>
  <li>sieve;</li>
  <li>skiff;</li>
  <li>vessel;</li>
</ul>

a

<ul class="fork">
  <li>beautiful</li>
  <li>shipshape</li>
  <li>sea worthy</li>
</ul>

<ul class="fork">
<li>craft,</li>
  <li>raft,</li>
  <li>wooden shoe,</li>
</ul>

certainly, though a

<ul class="fork">
  <li>good deal</li>
  <li>wee bit</li>
  <li>tad</li>
</ul>

too

<ul class="fork">
  <li>small</li>
  <li>high in the stern</li>
</ul>

to suit the two of them.

</div>

Which will result in this text being displayed:

An owl and a girl most
  • adventurous
  • curious
  • studious
  • set out
  • set sail
  • sailed away
in a
  • bottle-green
  • beetle-green

to suit the two of them.

A Timer

If you would like one of your forks to automatically change on a timer use the data-fork-timer attribute to set number of milliseconds for the interval. 

<ul class="fork" data-fork-timer="3000">
  <li>adventurous</li>
  <li>curious</li>
  <li>studious</li>
</ul>

Some Style

You can override the appearance of your forked text by simply providing your own CSS style. For example if you wanted all your forks to be underlined and blue; 

<style>
  .fork li {
    text-decoration: underline;
    color: blue;
  }
</style>

...

Interaction

If you want to provide a control to set all the forks use Fork.init function that gets imported into your page when you load the fork.js. 

<button onclick="Fork.init()">Fork</button>

Images

Since this is HTML you can put other things in your list than text. 

<ul class="fork">
  <li><img src="images/craft.png"></li>
  <li><img src="images/raft.png"></li>
  <li><img src="images/shoe.png"></li>
</ul>>
